meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny! Let's dive into the world of Deceive Inc., where sneaking and shooting come together like peanut butter and jelly. Well, sort of.

As you slip into the shoes of an undercover agent, you'll find that this game is all about strategy and teamwork - kind of like trying to get your friend to do a funny dance without them realizing what's up. Except instead of making dad jokes, you're taking down enemy agents and extracting top-secret intel (or not, because let's be real, it's all about the fun).

But don't just take my word for it! The critics are chiming in, and some are actually having a blast with this game. PC Gamer gives Deceive Inc. an 82 out of 100, saying it's a "creative blend of sneaking and shooting that will have squads coming back for more." High praise, if I do say so myself!

Meanwhile, The Games Machine thinks the game is doing something different from other competitive multiplayer titles - y'know, like putting on a funny hat to stand out in a crowd. They give it an 80, saying it's "a lot of fun" but needs more content and a premium season to keep things fresh.

Shacknews takes a slightly more laid-back approach, giving Deceive Inc. a 70. They think the game is "refreshing" and has some great ideas, even if it's not perfect just yet. And TheGamer agrees, sort of - they also give it a 70 and say it's fun enough to keep them playing solo mode while hoping for bug fixes.

GameSkinny, on the other hand, is a bit more...critical (heh). They think Deceive Inc. has some great mechanics, but is currently suffering from a lack of player base engagement - kind of like when your friend gets too into a game and forgets about the snacks. Ouch, harsh reviews are so fun to read!

Last but not least, NME gives Deceive Inc. an 80 and says it's a "fantastic" multiplayer game, just hamstrung by some minor annoyances. Yikes, sounds like they're giving it a hard time!

In the end, I think this game is worth checking out - after all, who doesn't love sneaking around, shooting things, and being a spy? It's not perfect, but hey, what game is? Even us critics can agree on that one.
